content:
Tracing through the definition of formal (co)limits in (−)∗:Toposco→TopLexcoop(-)^* : \mathrm{Topos}^{\mathrm{co}} \to \mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{coop}}(−)∗:Toposco→TopLexcoop:

  • First figure out what ◃\triangleleft◃ and ▹\triangleright▹ are:
    H(Toposco)(K⊙H,L)≅H(Toposco)(H,K▹L)≅H(Toposco)(K,L◃H)\mathscr{H}(\mathbb{T}\mathrm{opos}^{\mathrm{co}})(K \odot H, L) \cong \mathscr{H}(\mathbb{T}\mathrm{opos}^{\mathrm{co}})(H, K \triangleright L) \cong \mathscr{H}(\mathbb{T}\mathrm{opos}^{\mathrm{co}})(K, L \triangleleft H)H(Toposco)(K⊙H,L)≅H(Toposco)(H,K▹L)≅H(Toposco)(K,L◃H)
    TopLexcoop(HK,L)≅TopLexcoop(H,K▹L)≅TopLexcoop(K,L◃H)\mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{coop}}(HK,L) \cong \mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{coop}}(H, K \triangleright L) \cong \mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{coop}}(K, L \triangleleft H)TopLexcoop(HK,L)≅TopLexcoop(H,K▹L)≅TopLexcoop(K,L◃H)
    TopLex(L,KH)≅TopLex(K▹L,H)≅TopLex(L◃H,K)\mathrm{TopLex}(L,KH) \cong \mathrm{TopLex}(K \triangleright L, H) \cong \mathrm{TopLex}(L \triangleleft H, K)TopLex(L,KH)≅TopLex(K▹L,H)≅TopLex(L◃H,K)
    K▹L=LanKL,L◃H=LiftHLK \triangleright L = \mathrm{Lan}_{K} L, L \triangleleft H = \mathrm{Lift}_{H} LK▹L=LanK​L,L◃H=LiftH​L.

  • Now what are limits?
    C(1,limWF)≅C(1,F)◃WC(1,\mathrm{lim}_{W} F) \cong C(1,F) \triangleleft WC(1,limW​F)≅C(1,F)◃W (from [[proarrow equipment]])
    (limWF)∗≅LiftWF∗(\mathrm{lim}_{W} F)^{*} \cong \mathrm{Lift}_{W} F^{*}(limW​F)∗≅LiftW​F∗
    Lift(limWF)∗1C≅LiftWLiftF∗1C\mathrm{Lift}_{(\mathrm{lim}_{W} F)_{*}} 1_{C} \cong \mathrm{Lift}_{W} \mathrm{Lift}_{F_{*}} 1_{C}Lift(limW​F)∗​​1C​≅LiftW​LiftF∗​​1C​
    (limWF)∗≅F∗W(\mathrm{lim}_{W} F)_{*} \cong F_{*} W(limW​F)∗​≅F∗​W.

  • And colimits?
    C(colimWF,1)≅W▹C(F,1)C(\mathrm{colim}_{W} F,1) \cong W \triangleright C(F,1)C(colimW​F,1)≅W▹C(F,1) (is this correct?)
    (colimWF)∗≅LanWF∗(\mathrm{colim}_{W} F)_{*} \cong \mathrm{Lan}_{W} F_{*}(colimW​F)∗​≅LanW​F∗​
    Lan(colimWF)∗1C≅LanWLanF∗1C\mathrm{Lan}_{(\mathrm{colim}_{W} F)^{*}} 1_{C} \cong \mathrm{Lan}_{W} \mathrm{Lan}_{F^{*}} 1_{C}Lan(colimW​F)∗​1C​≅LanW​LanF∗​1C​
    (colimWF)∗≅WF∗(\mathrm{colim}_{W} F)^{*} \cong W F^{*}(colimW​F)∗≅WF∗.

You can embed diagrammatic limits and colimits in here using Psh\mathbb{P}\mathrm{sh}Psh. Looking at conical limits of diagrams, which we take as geometric morphisms from Psh(D)\mathbb{P}\mathrm{sh}(D)Psh(D) to E\mathcal{E}E, weighted by the locally constant sheaf functor on Psh(D)\mathbb{P}\mathrm{sh}(D)Psh(D):

(limf)∗=f∗LConst(\mathrm{lim} f)_{*} = f_{*} \mathrm {LConst}(limf)∗​=f∗​LConst (needs a lex left adjoint to be representable)
Set((limf)∗e,X)≅E(e,f∗(LConst(X)))≅SetDop(f∗(e),LConst(X))≅Set(colimf∗(e),X)\mathrm{Set}((\mathrm{lim} f)^{*} e, X) \cong \mathcal{E}(e, f_{*}(\mathrm{LConst}(X))) \cong \mathrm{Set}^{D^{\mathrm{op}}}(f^{*}(e), \mathrm{LConst}(X)) \cong \mathrm{Set}(\mathrm{colim} f^{*}(e), X)Set((limf)∗e,X)≅E(e,f∗​(LConst(X)))≅SetDop(f∗(e),LConst(X))≅Set(colimf∗(e),X).

The left adjoint is colimf∗(−)\mathrm{colim} f^{*}(-)colimf∗(−) but since f∗f^{*}f∗ is lex it is hard (impossible?) for this to be lex without the colimit commuting with finite limits in general in Set, which is to say being filtered. Because of variance this is the same as the original diagram being cofiltered, so in general it is only cofiltered limits among the small, diagrammatic, conical limits that exist in Toposco\mathbb{T}\mathrm{opos}^{\mathrm{co}}Toposco.

The situation with diagrammatic colimits is worse: you want a limit functor to have a right adjoint and this essentially never happens (only in the trivial case of the limit of the one-point diagram).

However, there are some other interesting limits and colimits that can exist. The conical colimit of the identity morphism exists when E\mathcal{E}E is a local topos and is equal to Γ⊣Codisc\Gamma \dashv \mathrm{Codisc}Γ⊣Codisc. The conical limit of the identity morphism exists when E\mathcal{E}E is a totally connected topos and is equal to Π0⊣Disc\Pi_{0} \dashv \mathrm{Disc}Π0​⊣Disc.

Why all this? I'm hoping someone will check my calculations, or know whether the things that seem impossible really are impossible, or come up with interesting nontrivial examples of nondiagrammatic or nonconical (co)limits that exist...

Also, these formal limits have "universal cones": one can construct a geometric morphism from Gl(W)\mathbf{Gl}(W)Gl(W) to E\mathcal{E}E that extends fff. Call it ddd:

  • d∗(x,y,u)=f∗(y)d_{*}(x,y,u) = f_{*}(y)d∗​(x,y,u)=f∗​(y)
  • d∗(e)=((LiftWf∗)(e),f∗(e),u)d^{*}(e) = ((\mathrm{Lift}_{W} f^{*})(e), f^{*}(e), u)d∗(e)=((LiftW​f∗)(e),f∗(e),u) where u:f∗(e)→(W∘LiftWf∗)(e)u : f^{*}(e) \to (W \circ \mathrm{Lift}_{W} f^{*})(e)u:f∗(e)→(W∘LiftW​f∗)(e) is the component of the unit(?) of the Lift ...
This ddd has a universal property that all domain extensions of fff to Gl(W)\mathbf{Gl}(W)Gl(W) through the canonical closed inclusion factor through ddd by a unique geometric transformation.
The limit of a connected geometric morphism weighted by its own inverse image functor is the identity. Trying to remember anything this might remind me of ...
You could call this the "pointwise right Kan extension" of the geometric morphism along itself. Ah, so this is saying that connected geometric morphisms are formally codense!
... and they seem to also be dense.
In general it looks like here codensity monads and density comonads are adjoints if both exist. Is that weird? It makes me wonder if I got the definition of colimit right.
It looks like in this setting, being formally dense, formally codense, and connected, are all equivalent properties. I wonder if nerve and realization works ...
...but I'm not sure how to define the nerve functor here, or even its codomain.
